ratings.comment: Loh is an excellent statistician but not a good lecturer. 40% midterm and 50% final. There are only a hundred pages of lecture slides throughout the semester, so be ready to read through them. The midterm was tricky, questions were never expected, and not the same as the practice exam if you have to take this class with him, good luck.

overall, a very nice professor and funny to listen to in class but;

- the course was extremely difficult
- lecture notes are just hundreds of pages of code output with barely any annotation
- if you miss what he says during a lecture there is no recording to look back on
- no help on homework during office hours, only in class during lecture.

Never separate lecture slides, put almost 200 pages in one file at mid-Nov :). Never answer any question about homework both in lectures and oh since it should be treated as "exams". Vague content in lecture. Hwk and exams are not very related.

I was not a stat student before and it is really hard for me to learn all these. He is away from the topics all the time. Lecturer has nothing to do with the exam and for a non-stats major student, I don't even know what those are all about. Moreover, I don't wanna be a statistician, I wanna be an ML engineer or data scientist

Professor Loh is a fantastic lecturer. Full of energy, a bit off the wall, knowledgable and application focused. You can't really go wrong with his classes. However, his lectures can be a bit daunting and paying attention in lecture is needed.

Wei Yin Loh is a very captivating lecturer. I wasn't once bored in his class. Although he is pioneer in his field, he is still very approachable and down to earth. I really enjoyed stat 443. 60% of your grade is the final project though.

An amiable professor always wears smiles. He loves sharing stories in class. He will teach from the principle and solve problems from a unique view. But the homework and exams are too tricky. Also, the textbook is useless, even in the open book exams. If you miss his class several times, just prepare to quit before the mid-term.
Nice professor, but there's no connection between HW and exam, very tricky exam, get prepared for it

The class was mostly based on 1 semester project and a series of small homework assignments. Multivariate analysis is an applied subject and professor Loh was sure to spend time on all of the important attribute of the subject and nothing that was not.

He is a a great teacher. Exams are ridiculously tricky and homeworks are nothing to do with exams.  Exams are not as straight forward as exams  and he can't provide any sample exam papers. This class should have at least one take home midterm instead of mid term and final.  If you not good at in class stat exams , just avoid this class.
Professor Loh really wants to us learn something not just remember. And his lecture is really inspirational sometimes.

Prof Loh is a nice guy. Always a big smile on his face. That's about it for his good qualities. He is an awful teacher. Mumbles to himself while he quickly writes stuff on an overhead. Really annoying. Exams were unfair. HW had absolutely NOTHING to do with the exams (esp. the final). Obviously too lazy to make his own HW. Only 1 midterm.

Professor Loh is very energetic when teaching the lecture. He makes sure that everyone understands why the formula is like that instead of just letting us memorize it. He truly cares about students and hope we can truly learn something from the class. He is also very fair about homework and grading. He is the best professor I've ever had so far.

Super nice guy. You need to know your stuff for his exams, and his open book policy isn't has helpful as you would think, because you are on a time crunch. But, his classes are curved and as long as you understand what he emphasizes in class and do the homework, you're golden. And R is a pain to use, but you'll get the hang of it
Easily one of the best in the Statistics Department
Super nice guy, willing to help. Exams are fair, book was really helpful. Grading/curving is very generous. Overall, the class was a pretty good experience

Makes funny jokes about statistics.  Expects class input from time to time (doesn't single you out though).  Enjoys visits to office hours.  Exams are exceedingly difficult (mean of 55-65), final is even harder. Rewards you for coming to lecture with data not in book.

BEST PROFESSOR EVER!!!   Most energetic person about stats I have ever seen.  Makes you want to learn and doesn't deal with teaching bull.  Material isn't  hard if you have any stats background, you have to try to not get a B or higher.  All you have to do is go to class an be active, do a little homework, and you should be fine on the the exams.
This class is extremly hard!!!  I never expected to spend so much time on one class.  He is a great teacher, but his exams are awful and you must fight for a B.
Very enthusiastic and friendly.  He will explain anything if you just ask.  Make sure to keep up in the homework and you'll be fine.
You'll hear the same analogies many times.  Not a difficult course, little to no time out of class required.
the average scores for the midterms were around 50-60 .. so don't expect to get easy A from his class  always tells jokes .. but not ... hmm you know what I mean
Perhaps the most excited person about statistics on the face of the planet. He does not make it easy, but if you put in a little extra effort you learn a ton!
Not a good professor at all. He treats students like 5-year-olds.
